chapters.name: The Idea of Pan-Africanism: Unity Across the Diaspora
topics: What is Pan-Africanism — the idea that all people of African descent share common interests and should work together?
How did the experience of slavery, colonialism, and racism create a shared identity among people of African descent across the globe?
What are the different strands of Pan-Africanism — cultural, political, economic, and continental?
How did early Pan-African thinkers like Edward Wilmot Blyden and Alexander Crummell articulate visions of African unity?
What is the relationship between Pan-Africanism and Black nationalism in the United States?
Why has Pan-Africanism persisted as a political idea despite the enormous diversity of African and diaspora communities?

chapters.name: W.E.B. Du Bois and the Pan-African Congresses
topics: How did W.E.B. Du Bois organize the first Pan-African Congresses beginning in 1919?
What demands did the Pan-African Congresses make — self-determination, an end to colonial exploitation, racial equality?
How did the congresses bring together Black intellectuals and activists from the Americas, the Caribbean, and Africa?
What was Du Bois's evolving vision of Pan-Africanism — from reformist appeals to radical anti-imperialism?
How did Du Bois's decision to relocate to Ghana in 1961 represent the fulfillment of his Pan-African vision?
What is the legacy of the Pan-African Congresses for contemporary movements for African unity?

chapters.name: Marcus Garvey and Mass Pan-Africanism
topics: How did Marcus Garvey build the Universal Negro Improvement Association into the largest mass movement of Black people in history?
What was Garvey's vision — racial pride, economic self-sufficiency, and the eventual return to Africa?
How did the Black Star Line shipping company represent Garvey's ambition for Black-controlled global commerce?
Why did Garvey's movement appeal to working-class Black people in ways that Du Bois's intellectual approach did not?
What caused Garvey's downfall — federal prosecution, internal conflicts, or the opposition of Black elites?
How did Garveyism influence later movements — Rastafari, Black Power, Afrocentrism?

chapters.name: African Independence Movements and Diaspora Connections
topics: How did the wave of African independence movements from the 1950s to 1970s inspire and connect with Black Americans?
What was Kwame Nkrumah's vision of a United States of Africa, and why did it fail to materialize?
How did the Bandung Conference of 1955 connect African, Asian, and diaspora liberation movements?
What role did diaspora activists play in supporting African independence — fundraising, lobbying, and solidarity organizing?
How did Patrice Lumumba's assassination and the Congo Crisis reveal the limits of African independence in a Cold War world?
What tensions existed between African independence leaders and diaspora Pan-Africanists about priorities and methods?

chapters.name: The Anti-Apartheid Movement and Global Black Solidarity
topics: How did the anti-apartheid movement become the most successful example of global Black solidarity in action?
What role did Black Americans play in pressuring the U.S. government and corporations to divest from South Africa?
How did the Free South Africa Movement, led by Randall Robinson and TransAfrica, mobilize protests across the United States?
What was the significance of Nelson Mandela's release and South Africa's democratic transition for Pan-Africanism?
How did the anti-apartheid movement demonstrate the power of sustained international pressure?
What lessons from the anti-apartheid struggle apply to contemporary movements for racial justice?

chapters.name: Caribbean Diaspora and Black Identity
topics: How did Caribbean intellectual traditions — from C.L.R. James to Frantz Fanon to Stuart Hall — shape global Black thought?
What was the Negritude movement, and how did Aimé Césaire and Léopold Sédar Senghor articulate a philosophy of Black cultural pride?
How did Frantz Fanon's The Wretched of the Earth become a foundational text for anti-colonial and Black liberation movements worldwide?
What is the relationship between Caribbean and African American identities — shared heritage, different histories, occasional tensions?
How has Caribbean migration to the United States, Britain, and Canada created new dimensions of Black diaspora identity?
What role does Rastafari play as a Caribbean Pan-African spiritual and political movement?

chapters.name: Afrocentrism and the Cultural Connection to Africa
topics: What is Afrocentrism, and how did Molefi Kete Asante articulate it as an intellectual framework centering African experience?
How did the Afrocentric movement promote African names, clothing, celebrations like Kwanzaa, and connections to African heritage?
What role has DNA ancestry testing played in reconnecting diaspora communities with specific African origins?
What criticisms have been leveled against Afrocentrism — essentialism, historical inaccuracy, romanticization of Africa?
How do contemporary Africans view diaspora Afrocentrism — as solidarity, misunderstanding, or both?
What is the difference between cultural connection to Africa and political Pan-Africanism?

chapters.name: Black British, Afro-European, and Global Diaspora Experiences
topics: How does the Black British experience differ from and parallel the African American experience?
What was the Windrush generation, and how did Caribbean migration to Britain shape Black British identity?
How do Afro-European communities in France, Germany, the Netherlands, and other countries navigate race and national identity?
What is the Black experience in Latin America — Brazil, Colombia, Cuba — where large African-descended populations face distinct forms of racism?
How do global diaspora communities connect with each other and with Africa in the age of social media?
What does it mean to be Black in a global context — is there a shared identity or are the differences more significant?

chapters.name: Contemporary Pan-Africanism and the African Union
topics: How does the African Union attempt to realize Pan-African political unity on a continental scale?
What is the AU's Agenda 2063 vision for African development and continental integration?
How has the AU designated the African diaspora as a 'sixth region' of Africa?
What role do remittances from diaspora communities play in African economic development?
How are contemporary African artists, writers, and musicians creating a new Pan-African cultural space?
What are the prospects for Pan-Africanism in the 21st century — is continental unity closer or further away?

chapters.name: Afrofuturism and Imagining Pan-African Futures
topics: How does Afrofuturism reimagine African and diaspora futures through science fiction, art, and technology?
What is the significance of Black Panther's Wakanda as a vision of an uncolonized, technologically advanced African nation?
How do Afrofuturist artists connect African past, present, and future — mythology, technology, and liberation?
What role does technology play in contemporary Pan-African connection — from social media to fintech to satellite communications?
How are young Africans and diaspora youth creating new forms of Pan-African identity through music, fashion, and digital culture?
What would a realized Pan-African future look like — politically, economically, and culturally?
